text: Bryan F. Shaw (born August 20, 1976) is an American biochemist at Baylor University in Waco, Texas.National Public Radio, Shots, November 6, 2013; https://www.npr.org/blogs/health/2013/11/05/243189819/how-pictures-of-infant- boys-eyes-helped-diagnose-cancer He is best known for developing free software for smartphones that can detect eye cancer (retinoblastoma) in children by searching the child's picture for "white eye" (leukocoria).National Public Radio, Morning Edition, October 31, 2014; https://www.npr.org/blogs/health/2014/10/31/359568507/look-here-phone-app- checks-photos-for-eye-diseaseKEYE TV, CBS Austin, November 7, 2014; CBS Dallas/Fort Worth, May 19, 2014; http://dfw.cbslocal.com/2014/05/19/white-eye- photos-may-indicate-rare-cancer-in-children/ Shaw developed this software after his wife detected "white eye" in pictures of their own son, who was later diagnosed with retinoblastoma.National Public Radio, Morning Edition, May 6, 2014; https://www.npr.org/blogs/health/2014/05/06/309003098/chemist- turns-software-developer-after-sons-cancer-diagnosis Shaw is an advocate for parent-based, photographic screening of pediatric eye diseases that present with "white-eye".National Public Radio, Morning Edition, May 7, 2014; https://www.npr.org/blogs/health/2014/05/07/310104315/faith-drives-a-father- to-create-a-test-for-childhood-cancerBritish Broadcasting Company, November 12, 2014; Shaw grew up in Spokane, Washington and received his Ph.D. in chemistry at the University of California, Los Angeles.
